Catalytic performance of metal azolate frameworks in the solventless synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides Han-Ung Kim Robin Babu Roshith Roshan Dae-Won Park ⁎ Division of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Pusan National University, Busan, 609-735, Republic of Korea Division of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Pusan National University Busan 609-735 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Two types of metal azolate frameworks (MAFs) with uncoordinated and coordinated nitrogen atoms composed of zinc coordinated with 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole and 3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazole linkers denoted as MAF-66 and MAF-X5, respectively have been synthesized and characterized using various physicochemical techniques. The uncoordinated N donors present in the MAFs show high adsorption affinity for carbon dioxide. The synthesized MAFs showed promising catalytic activity towards the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide and epoxides under solvent-free conditions with excellent selectivity towards the desired five-membered cyclic carbonates. The importance of uncoordinated N donors and amine groups in the effective catalysis of the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides was investigated. Both catalysts were separable by simple filtration and reusable without any considerable loss in the initial activity. Various reaction parameters including temperature, reaction time, and CO2 pressure were studied. A possible reaction mechanism explaining the role of amine groups in the cycloaddition reaction was proposed based on literature and experimental inferences. Keywords MAF-66 MAF-X5 Carbon dioxide Epoxide Cyclic carbonate 1 Introduction Our planet is currently under the threat of global warming, and it is high time to take steps to regain the carbon cycle balance. Since CO2 is the major greenhouse gas formed by human activities, its capture and sequestration are highly essential. Several technologies are being proposed for the capture and sequestration of carbon dioxide. The nonflammable and harmless nature of CO2 makes it an easily usable feedstock, while its abundance and inexpensiveness are benefits from the economic perspective [1–3]. Thus, the effective conversion of captured CO2 into various chemicals, such as cyclic carbonates, formic acid, N,Ń-disubstituted ureas, and urethanes, has attracted a great deal of attention from researchers [4–7]. The production of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides is fully atom-economical and uses safe CO2 gas as a raw material instead of toxic gases such as phosgene or isocyanate. Cyclic carbonates have found a wide range of applications in different fields; for example, they have been used as electrolytes in lithium ion batteries and starting materials for a variety of polycarbonates and in pharmaceuticals and agriculture. Being the most oxidized form of carbon, CO2 is chemically less reactive [8–11]. This thermodynamic and chemical stability makes its transformation impossible under standard conditions. However, treating CO2 with a highly reactive substrate may help to some extent in overcoming the energy barrier, and this could be realized with a catalyst. In the past, several homogeneous catalysts, which included quaternary ammonium salts, metal halides, and metal complexes, were reported to be efficient in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates [12–21]. However, because of the difficulties associated with catalyst recycling, highly efficient heterogeneous catalysts are demanded. Various heterogeneous catalysts, which include metal oxides [22–24], zeolites [25], titanosilicates, ion-exchange resins [26–33], and metal organic frameworks [34–46], have been found to effectively catalyze the epoxide-CO2 cycloaddition reaction. Metal azolate frameworks (MAFs) have been explored as porous materials for various catalytic applications. Compared to other metal-ligand systems, MAFs have highly predictable coordination geometries and connectivities [47,48]. One of the main characteristic properties of azoles is that nitrogen-only azoles can be deprotonated to form the respective azolate anions [49,50]. Owing to this deprotonation, all of the N atoms will coordinate with metal ions. Furthermore, these deprotonations will increase their basicity. Consequently, the MAFs will be highly thermally and chemically stable. Very recently, research has proved that the presence of uncoordinated triazolate N donors exposed on a pore surface can increase CO2 uptake by over 100% [51–54]. The adsorption affinity for CO2 is very high in the presence of uncoordinated N donors. In this study, we synthesized two types of MAFs with coordinated and uncoordinated nitrogen atoms in their frameworks. The importance of uncoordinated N donors and amine groups in the effective catalysis of the solvent-free cycloaddition of carbon dioxide with epoxides was investigated using various experimental and physicochemical characterization techniques, and the results were compared with those of an MAF catalytic system in which all nitrogen atoms are coordinated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts For the preparation of [Zn(atz)2]·guest (MAF-66), 73mg of 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole (atz) was dissolved in 50mL of isopropyl alcohol and 40mg of Zn(OH)2 was dissolved in 50mL of a 25% aqueous ammonia solution. The solutions were mixed together and stirred for several minutes. The final solution was left at room temperature for 3 d to evaporate slowly. The obtained colorless crystals were centrifuged and washed three times with water and isopropyl alcohol, and then air-dried. Elem. Anal. Calcd. (%) for C7H15.2N8O1.6Zn ([Zn(atz)2]·0.6H2O·1.0C3H8O): C, 27.80; H, 5.07; N, 37.05; Zn, 21.62. Found: C, 27.83; H, 4.86; N, 37.02; Zn, 22.77. For the preparation of [Zn(dmtz)F] (MAF-X5), 0.119g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.04g of Hdmtz (3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazole) were separately dissolved in 0.4mmol of hydrofluoric acid (47%) and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (4mL), respectively. The resultant solutions were stirred for several minutes, and then placed in a 20mL stainless steel Teflon-lined autoclave and heated for 72h at 90°C. After the reaction mixture was cooled down slowly, the resultant colorless needle-shaped crystals were centrifuged, washed with DMF and methanol, and air-dried. Elem. Anal. Calcd. (%) for C4H6FN3Zn: C, 26.62; H, 3.35; N, 23.28; Zn, 36.22. Found: C, 26.58; H, 3.38; N, 23.21, Zn, 34.54. 2.2 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a PANalytical X'pert PRO powder diffractometer (CuKα radiation, λ =1.5Å). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy was carried out using an AVATAR 370 Thermo Nicolet spectrophotometer (FT-IR resolution of 4cm−1). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Netzsch ST 449 instrument. The morphologies of both catalysts were examined using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) with an S-4200 microscope (Hitachi–3500N). Elemental analysis (EA) was performed using a Vario ELIII system using sulfanilic acid as the standard. The metal contents of both MAFs were determined using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) using ULTIMA2CHR (1.5kW, 40.68MHz, 130–800mm) with mono chromato HDD and a poly chromato PMT detector. CO2 and NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) data were obtained with a chemisorption analyzer (BEL-CAT). 2.3 Cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides The cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides were performed in a 25mL stainless steel autoclave. Reactions were performed under different reaction conditions (different temperatures, catalyst/co-catalyst ratios, time intervals, etc.) by using different epoxides. In a typical experiment, epichlorohydrin (ECH (38.3mmol)), catalyst (MAF-66 or MAF-X5 (0.3mol% each)), and co-catalyst (tetrabutylammonium halide such as tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB), tetrabutylammonium iodide (TBAI), and tetrabutylammonium chloride (TBAC) (0.3mol%)) were added to the reactor. The reactor was pressurized with CO2 and it was heated to a pre-set temperature. Then the reaction was started by stirring at 600rpm. After the reaction was finished, the heating and stirring were stopped and the reaction mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature. The catalyst was separated through centrifugation, and the products were analyzed using a gas chromatography (GC) apparatus Agilent HP 6890A, flame ionization detector, toluene as the internal standard, oven temperature: from 40°C to 250°C (10°C per min) equipped with a capillary column (HP-5, 30m×0.25μm). Recycling experiments were carried out for both MAF-66 and MAF-X5 under the optimized reaction conditions chosen from the preliminary experiments. After the reactions were finished, the catalysts were separated through centrifugation, washed with methanol, and vacuum dried at 100°C for 12h. The recovered catalysts were tested again five times using the procedures mentioned above to evaluate their recyclability. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts MAF-66 adopts a 3D structural framework and crystallizes in a cubic system [54]. The asymmetric unit consists of one Zn atom coordinated with imidazolate-type atz ligands, which results in the formation of a distorted dia topology. The adjacent Zn–Zn distance was measured to be approximately 6.03Å. The coordination environments created by ligands around Zn2+ centers are shown in Scheme 1 . MAF-X5 consists of a Zn atom coordinated with three nitrogen atoms from three different dmtz ligands, which results in the formation of a 3D framework with distorted trigonal-bipyramidal geometry. The Zn-N distance was measured to be in the 2.035–2.10Å range, whereas the Zn-F distance was found to be approximately 1.99Å. The powder XRD patterns of the as-synthesized MAF-66 and MAF-X5 catalysts were compared with a simulated pattern reported in the literature (Figs. 1 and 2 ). All of the peaks were in good agreement with those of the simulated XRD pattern, which confirms the crystallinity of the synthesized samples. The FT-IR spectra of both MAF-66 and MAF-X5 are shown in Fig. 3 . For MAF-66, the band at 3426cm−1 is attributed to the N−H stretching vibration, and the peaks at around 1650–1450cm−1 are attributed to the N−H bending vibration. The peaks at around 1600–1500cm−1 correspond to C=N stretching vibrations. The presence of a Zn−N bond peak at 500cm−1 proves the successful formation of the MAF. For MAF-X5, the peaks at around 1563–1456cm−1 correspond to Zn−F stretching vibrations. The morphologies of both the MAF-66 and MAF-X5 catalysts are shown in Figs. 4 and 5 . MAF-X5 was found to form needle-shaped crystals whereas MAF-66 was found to form an octahedral shape with dia topology. The thermal stabilities of both MAF-66 and MAF-X5 were evaluated using TGA (Fig. 6 ). MAF-66 showed a small weight loss at around 90°C (2.7wt%), corresponding to the loss of isopropyl alcohol. The major weight loss was found to occur at around 320°C (14.7wt%), indicating that the framework is thermally stable up to approximately 320°C. Meanwhile, the major weight loss for MAF-X5 was found at around 400°C (14.9wt%), indicating that MAF-X5 is thermally stable up to approximately 400°C. The oxidation states of the Zn(II) metal centers for both MAF-66 and MAF-X5 were verified through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis (Figs. S1 and S2). CO2- and NH3-TPD analyses were performed on both catalysts to examine the acid-base characteristics. The total adsorbed CO2 for MAF-66 was estimated to be 27mmolg−1. The −NH2 groups of the ligand and the N atoms present in the frameworks are expected to be responsible for CO2 adsorption. Similarly, in NH3-TPD, the concentration of acid sites was found to be 0.568mmolg−1, which is consistent with that of the Zn metal centers (Figs. S3 and S4). For MAF-X5, CO2-TPD gave a value of approximately 2.2mmolg−1 and NH3-TPD gave a value of approximately 0.048mmolg−1 (Figs. S5 and S6). 3.2 Cycloaddition of CO2 with epichlorohydrin The catalytic potentials of both MAF-66 and MAF-X5 were investigated in the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epichlorohydrin (Scheme 2 ). The reactions were carried out at 80°C and a CO2 pressure of 1.2MPa for 6h. No significant conversion of epichlorohydrin occurred with both MAF-66 and MAF-X5 in 6h (Table 1 , entries 2 and 3). However, a drastic increase in the epichlorohydrin conversion was observed when common co-catalysts such as TBAB were used under the same reaction conditions. This result clearly proves that the CO2-to-oxirane coupling is synergistically enhanced by Lewis acidic sites (Zn2+) and nucleophilic anions (Br−). Approximately 92% epichlorohydrin conversion was observed with MAF-66/TBAB (Table 1, entry 5). MAF-X5/TBAB gave a lower epichlorohydrin conversion (83%) than the MAF-66/TBAB system did (Table 1, entry 7). Almost 100% selectivity was retained by both catalysts throughout the reaction. MAF-66 has amine groups and uncoordinated nitrogen atoms in its framework. These can polarize CO2 molecules easily, resulting in higher catalytic activity than that of MAF-X5 with fully coordinated nitrogen frameworks. Another set of experiments was performed with the precursors of the MAF-66 and MAF-X5 catalysts (Table 1, entries 6 and 8). Zn(OH)2/Hatz/TBAB was found to give approximately 87% conversion under the same reaction conditions as those employed for MAF-66. Even though it showed good catalytic activity, the recyclability and reusability of this system limit its applications on the industrial level. This highlights the importance of heterogeneous MAF catalysts with high catalytic activity, which can be used to overcome the limitations of conventional homogeneous catalysts. The active metal centers and the CO2 adsorption capabilities of the MAF network must have been the driving forces behind the efficient catalysis. Cycloaddition reactions were also performed using TBAI and TBAC co-catalysts to study the effect of the halide ions in the tetraalkyl ammonium salt. The results are given in Tables 2 and 3 . The highest activity was obtained with I−, followed by Br− and then Cl−, which was consistent with previous literature reports in which iodides showed the highest activity (order of increasing nucleophilicity). Various reaction parameters such as the amount of catalyst, temperature, time, and CO2 pressure were studied with both MAF-66 and MAF-X5 for the optimization of the conditions for the cycloaddition reactions. Fig. S7 shows the effect of the reaction time on the cycloaddition reaction catalyzed by both MAF-66 and MAF-X5 in the presence of TBAB at 1.2MPa of CO2 with reaction times ranging from 3 to 12h at a reaction temperature of 80°C. For both catalysts, the yield of chloropropene carbonate was found to increase with increasing time and approached almost 100% after 12h. The effects of the temperature on the catalysis of the cycloaddition reaction were studied with both MAF-66 and MAF-X5 under the reaction conditions of 1.2MPa of CO2 for 6h (Fig. S8). The yield of chloropropene carbonate was found to increase when the temperature was in the 40–100°C range, reaching its maximum at a reaction temperature of 100°C. A similar trend in catalytic activity was observed for the MAF-X5/TBAB catalyst system. The effect of the CO2 pressure on the catalytic activities of both MAF-66 and MAF-X5 was studied at 80°C using pressures ranging from 0.6 to 1.8MPa, and the results are shown in Fig. S9. For MAF-66, the yield of chloropropene carbonate was found to increase from 74% to 92% and then increase slightly to 96% when the CO2 pressure reached 1.8MPa. These results prove that the catalytic activities of the MAFs depend on the concentration of available CO2 at the reactive sites. The same variation in catalytic activity with the CO2 pressure was observed for the MAF-X5/TBAB catalyst system. The yield of chloropropene carbonate increased steadily from 72% to 83% when the pressure was increased from 0.6 to 1.2MPa, and reached a maximum of 88% at 1.8MPa of CO2. The effects of the amount of catalyst on the catalytic performances of both MAF-66 and MAF-X5 were studied using catalyst loadings ranging from 0.1 to 0.5mol% with 38.3mmol of ECH at 80°C and 1.2MPa of CO2 for 6h. As shown in Fig. S10, a considerable change in the chloropropene carbonate yield was observed when the amount of catalyst was increased from 0.1 (70%) to 0.3mol% (92%) for the MAF-66/TBAB catalyst system. A maximum conversion of 96% was observed for MAF-66 at 0.5mol% of catalyst under the same reaction conditions. A similar trend in catalytic activity was observed for the MAF-X5/TBAB catalyst system. The coupling reactions of CO2 with different epoxides catalyzed by both MAF-66 and MAF-X5 in the presence of TBAB were studied, and the results are summarized in Tables 4 and 5 . Both MAF-66 and MAF-X5 were suitable for terminal epoxides, showing high activity towards cyclic carbonates. Cyclohexene oxide showed the lowest activity among these. The electronic effect together with the steric effect would be the reason for the decrease in the catalytic activity of cyclohexene oxide [55–57]. Recyclability studies for both MAF-66 and MAF-X5 were carried out using the reaction of ECH with CO2; recyclability is considered to be an important criterion in determining the stability and efficiency of a material. MAF-66 (Fig. 7 ) was found to show a slight decrease in the chloropropene carbonate yield in each cycle, which may be because of the loss of its regular porous structure. However, the activity (83%) and selectivity (>99%) of MAF-X5 (Fig. 8 ) were preserved after being recycled the first five times, showing the stability of the MAF, which is due to its stable framework structure. The XRD and FT-IR peaks of MAF-X5 after being recycled five times were similar to those of the freshly prepared catalysts (Figs. S11 and S12). This clearly indicates the chemical stability of both MAF-66 and MAF-X5 as heterogeneous catalysts, not only for CO2 insertion reactions, but also for other catalytic applications. 3.3 Reaction mechanism Scheme 3 shows a possible mechanism behind the cycloaddition reaction of an epoxide and CO2 catalyzed by a zinc-based MAF to produce cyclic carbonates. The reaction commences with the activation of the epoxide oxygen by the Lewis acidic Zn(II) metal center. Subsequently, the Br− of TBAB attacks the least hindered carbon atom, resulting in the opening of the epoxide ring. In the case of MAF-66, CO2 is polarized by the presence of amine groups as well as the uncoordinated nitrogen atoms present in the framework, and then CO2 insertion occurs in the following step, which leads to the formation of a carbonate complex [56–61]. Finally, the ring closes upon the elimination of the halide ion to generate the cyclic carbonate. In the case of MAF-X5, ring opening occurs and the bromide ion from the TBAB co-catalyst attacks the β-carbon atom of the epoxide. This results in the formation of an alkoxy halide intermediate, which reacts with CO2 to form a carbonate complex. Finally, the halide ion leaves the system and cycloaddition commences to afford the desired cyclic carbonate and regenerate the catalyst. The high thermal stability, high CO2 adsorption affinity, and presence of Lewis acid/base sites made the MAFs promising candidates for CO2 transformation reactions. MAF-X5 and MAF-66 were found to be stable at around 400°C. Both catalytic systems were shown to catalyze the CO2-epoxide cycloaddition reaction under mild conditions with 99% selectivity. The presence of amine groups as well as the uncoordinated nitrogen atoms in the framework of MAF-66 enabled it to give higher conversions than those given by MAF-X5. 4 Conclusion In this work, two types of MAFs with uncoordinated and coordinated nitrogen atoms composed of zinc coordinated with 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole and 3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazole linkers were synthesized and characterized using various physicochemical techniques. High catalytic activities were obtained in the cycloaddition of ECH and CO2 with both MAF-66 and MAF-X5 with TBAB as a co-catalyst under mild reaction conditions with high selectivity for chloropropene carbonate (>99%). The importance of uncoordinated N donors and amine groups in the effective catalysis of CO2-epoxide cycloaddition reactions was investigated. Various reaction parameters such as the reaction time, temperature, amount of catalyst, and pressure were investigated. After carefully studying the effects of various reaction parameters, we found the optimal reaction conditions that give high conversions with excellent selectivity. For both catalysts, high conversions and selectivities were obtained using 0.3mol% each of the catalyst and co-catalyst, a temperature of 80°C, a reaction time of 6h, and a CO2 pressure of 1.2MPa. Both catalysts were reusable following simple filtration. A reaction mechanism was suggested based on experimental results and our previous density functional theory studies. coredata.dc:description: Two types of metal azolate frameworks (MAFs) with uncoordinated and coordinated nitrogen atoms composed of zinc coordinated with 3-amino-1,2,4-triazole and 3,5-dimethyl-1,2,4-triazole linkers denoted as MAF-66 and MAF-X5, respectively have been synthesized and characterized using various physicochemical techniques. The uncoordinated N donors present in the MAFs show high adsorption affinity for carbon dioxide. The synthesized MAFs showed promising catalytic activity towards the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide and epoxides under solvent-free conditions with excellent selectivity towards the desired five-membered cyclic carbonates. The importance of uncoordinated N donors and amine groups in the effective catalysis of the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides was investigated. Both catalysts were separable by simple filtration and reusable without any considerable loss in the initial activity. Various reaction parameters including temperature, reaction time, and CO2 pressure were studied. A possible reaction mechanism explaining the role of amine groups in the cycloaddition reaction was proposed based on literature and experimental inferences.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic performance of metal azolate frameworks in the solventless synthesis of cyclic carbonates from CO2 and epoxides
